contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox German district| name=Günzburg| state=Bavaria| capital=[[Günzburg]]| regierungsbezirk=[[Swabia (administrative region)|Swabia]]| region=Donau-Iller| area=763|Kreisschlüssel = 09774 | population=121,600| population_as_of=2000| density=159| carsign=GZ| url=[http://www.landkreis-guenzburg.de landkreis-guenzburg.de]| map=Bavaria gz.png }} '''Günzburg''' is a district in [[Bavaria]], [[Germany]]. It is bounded by (from the north and clockwise) the districts of [[Dillingen (district)|Dillingen]], [[Augsburg (district)|Augsburg]], [[Unterallgäu]] and [[Neu-Ulm (district)|Neu-Ulm]], and by the state of [[Baden-Württemberg]] (districts [[Alb-Donau (district)|Alb-Donau]] and [[Heidenheim (district)|Heidenheim]]). ''For the capital, see [[Günzburg]].'' ==History== In the early Middle Ages the tiny county of [[Burgau]] ruled the region. In 1213 the county was acquired by the lords of [[Berg (German region)|Berg]]; it was then known as Berg-Burgau, but the last ruler of this collateral line died in 1301, and [[Burgau]] (now raised to the level of a [[margraviate]]) became an exclave of [[Austria]]. In the early 17th century the administrative seat was moved from the town of Burgau to Günzburg, but the [[margraviate]] retained its name. When the [[Holy Roman Empire]] ceased to exist in 1806, the [[margraviate]] was dissolved and the region was annexed by [[Bavaria]]. The district was established in 1972 by merging the former districts of Günzburg and [[Krumbach, Swabia (district)|Krumbach]]. [[Günzburg]] lost its status as an [[List of German urban districts|urban district]] and became the administrative seat of the new district. ==Geography== The [[Danube]] river and its tributaries characterise this district. The Danube runs through the northernmost parts of the district, passing the cities of Günzburg and Leipheim. There are several affluents coming from the south, for example [[Biber]], [[Günz]] and [[Mindel]]. Most of the district's area is covered with forests; the eastern third of the territory is part of the ''Augsburg Western Forests Nature Park''. ==Coat of arms== {| |- valign=top ||[[image:Wappen Landkreis Guenzburg.svg|110px|Coat of arms]] ||On the right there are the old arms of the margravate of Burgau: red and white with a yellow beam. The eagle is from the arms of the Schwabegg-Ursberg family, which founded two monasteries in the district. |} ==Towns and municipalities== [[File:1 Landkreis GZ englisch.png|right|thumb|300px|map of the district of Günzburg]] {| ! align=left width=33%|Towns ! align=left width=33%|Municipalities |- valign=top || #[[Burgau]] #[[Günzburg]] #[[Ichenhausen]] #[[Krumbach, Bavaria|Krumbach]] #[[Leipheim]] #[[Thannhausen]] || #[[Aichen]] #[[Aletshausen]] #[[Balzhausen]] #[[Bibertal]] #[[Breitenthal]] #[[Bubesheim]] #[[Burtenbach]] #[[Deisenhausen]] #[[Dürrlauingen]] #[[Ebershausen]] #[[Ellzee]] #[[Gundremmingen]] #[[Haldenwang]] #[[Jettingen-Scheppach]] || <ol start=15> <li> [[Kammeltal]] <li> [[Kötz]] <li> [[Landensberg]] <li> [[Münsterhausen]] <li> [[Neuburg an der Kammel]] <li> [[Offingen]] <li> [[Rettenbach, Swabia|Rettenbach]] <li> [[Röfingen]] <li> [[Ursberg]] <li> [[Waldstetten, Bavaria|Waldstetten]] <li> [[Waltenhausen]] <li> [[Wiesenbach, Bavaria|Wiesenbach]] <li> [[Winterbach, Bavaria|Winterbach]] <li> [[Ziemetshausen]] </ol> |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Landkreis Günzburg}} *{{de icon}} [http://www.landkreis-guenzburg.de Official website] {{Germany_districts_bavaria}} {{Coord|48.33|10.33|display=title|format=dms}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gunzburg (District)}} [[Category:Günzburg (district)| ]] [[Category:Districts of Bavaria]]
